File.Title: Distribution of Locus Coeruleus Axons Within the Rat Brainstem Demonstrated by PhaseoZus uuZgaris Leucoagglutinin Anterograde Tracing in Combination With Dopamine-@-Hy droxylase Immunofluorescence

Abstract.S: Projections of the locus coeruleus (LC) to the midbrain and hindbrain were analyzed by anterograde transport of the lectin Phaseolus uulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-I,).

Following iontophoretic application of PHA-L into the LC, the distribution of labeled axons was analyzed in sections processed for the immunoperoxidase method and in sections processed for double-immunofluorescence staining using antibodies to PHA-L and to dopamine-/-hydroxylase.

This combined staining approach proved to be necessary for the unequivocal identification of I,C axons in the brainstem since all injections labeled many non-noradrenergic axons whose distribution was different from that of LC fibers.
The major new finding of the present study was the observation that large territories of the brainstem that receive a dense noradrenergic input are very sparsely innervated by the LC.
Numerous labeled LC axons were observed in somatic afferent nuclei, tectum, pontine nuclei, interpeduncular nucleus, and inferior olivary complex.
In contrast. very few labeled fibers were observed in autonomic and motor nuclei, and throughout the brainstem reticular formation, including raphe nuclei.
Our data show that the distribution of LC axons in the brainstem is far less prominent than the projections of this nucleus to the forebrain and spinal cord.
Our findings suggest that the dense NA projections to the core of the brainstem originate principally in non-LC NA neurons.
On the basis of the present anatomical findings, a prominent role of the LA2 in motor and integrative functions of the brainstem appears unlikely.

Introduction.S: The locus coeruleus (LC) is the principal source of ascending noradrenergic (NA) projections to the forebrain, including the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, thalamus, and olfactory bulb (Ungerstedt, '71; Iindvall and Bjdrklund, '74; Ross and Reis, '74; Swanson and Hartman, '74; Levitt and Moore. '78; Morrison et al., '79. '81; see Bjiirklund and Lindvall, '86, for review).
Prominent descending projections from the LC to the spinal cord have also been described (Rjorklund and Skagerherg, '82; Lyons et al., '89; Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
While LC efferents to the forebrain and spinal cord have been characterized in considerable detail, LC projections to the brainstem have received much less attention.
The distribution of' catecholamine axon terminals within the brainstem was initially described by Fuxe ('65).
Ungerstedt ('71) concluded that these terminals originate from the LC and from the A l , A2, A5, and A7 groups of Dahlstriim and Fuxe ('64).

While acknowledging the lack of details ahout the origin of NA terminals, LJngerstedt ('71) suspected that projections of LC and non-LC NA neurons overlap in the hindbrain and that most NA terminals in the midbrain originate in non-LC NA cells.

Later studies involving lesions of the LC suggested that this nucleus distributes axons to widespread areas of the brainstem, including the tectum, mesencephalic central gray, dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus nerve, nucleus of the solitary tract, commissural nucleus, hypoglossal nucleus, and raphe nuclei (Loizou, '69; Chu and Bloom, '74; Kobayashi et, al., '74; Ross and Reis, '74).

Early studies of T,C projections with the newly introduced method of anterograde transport of tritiated amino acids made only brief references to the distribution of LC axons within the brainstem (Pickel et al., '74; McBride and S u h , '76; Jones and Moore, '77; Bowden et al., '78).
The resulk of recent studies using this method support the conclusion that LC neurons have widespread projections to numerous brainstem areas (Westlund and Coulter, '80; Jones and Yang, '85).
A rather different pattern of LC axon distribution was described by Levitt and Moore ('79), who conducted the first comprehensive study of the organization of NA projections to the brainstem.
These authors observed that bilateral destruction of the LC resulted in decreases in norepinephrine levels in the brainstem with a rather distinct regional pattern.
They concluded that the LC supplies NA axons primarily to sensory and association nuclei of the brainstem, whereas non-LC NA neurons innervate motor nuclei and autonomic areas.
Their results showed that most of the NA innervation of the medulla originates from nonLC NA neurons.

The differential origin of NA axons in sensory and motor nuclei was subsequently confirmed by several retrograde transport studies (Kromer and Moore, '80; Senba et al., '81; Travers and Norgren, '83; Vornov and Sutin, '83; Grzanna et al., '87; 1,yons and Grzanna, '88).

The description by Levitt and Moore ('79) of the LC axon distribution within the brainstem differs substantially from that provided by the results of anterograde transport studies with tritiated amino acids.
Detailed knowledge of the anatomic distribution of LC axons within the brainstem is essential for an understanding of the role of this nucleus in functions such as sleep or cardiovascular regulation.
Recently, a new and powerful tracing method was introduced by Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84), which employs anterograde transport of the lectin Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin.

This method is extremely sensitive and offers the unique advantage that it can readily be combined with immunohistochemical identification of NA axons (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '85; Fritschy et al., '87; Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).

In the present study, we have used the PHA-L method in combination with dopamine-p-hydroxylase (DRH) immunohistochemistry (Hartman, '73; Grzanna et al., '77) to provide a comprehensive description of the distribution of LC axons within the brainstem.
A preliminary report of this study has been presented (Grzanna and Fritschy, '87).

Methods.S: METHODS
Male Sprague-Dawley rats weighing 170-180 g were employed.
A detailed protocol of the PHA-L method used here is given in a previous report (Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
To study the distribution of LC axons in the brainstem (midbrain and hindbrain) small deposits of PHA-L were made iontophoretically under stereotaxic guidance into t.he LC.
After a survival period of 2-3 weeks, rats were anesthetized with chloral hydrate and perfused according to a modification of the pH-shift method of Berod et al. ('81).
Following postfixation and cryoprotection, 30 wm transverse sections were cut from frozen blocks by using a sliding microt,ome.
Three sets of brainstem sections were collected in PBS and processed separately: one set was processed for the immunoperoxidase method of Hsu et al.
('Sl), using antibodies against PHA-L (Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
In these sections we studied the distribution of PHA-L labeled axons in darkfield at low power.

The second set of sections was processed for double-immunofluorescence (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '85) by using antibodies against PHA-L raised in rabbits and antibodies against DBH raised in guinea pigs (Grzanna and Coyle, '76).
These sections were examined at high magnification to recognize LC axons from other PHAL labeled fibers.
Since the LC comprises NA neurons entirely (Swanson, '76), only those PHA-L labeled fibers that were also DBH-positive were considered as LC axons.
The third set of sections was stained with Cresyl violet and used for cytoarchitectonic reference purposes.
PHA-L immunohis tochemistry

For staining of PHA-L with the immunoperoxidase method, sections were incubated overnight in antibodies against PHA-L (1:2,000) and processed by using the Vectastain kit (Vector Laboratories) (Hsu et al., '81).
The sections were processed in a solution of 0.05 % diaminobenzidine and 0.005':b hydrogen peroxide in 'his buffer (0.05 M, pH 7.7) for 10-20 minutes, rinsed, and mounted onto gelatin-coated slides.
The staining was enhanced with osmium tetroxide according to the procedure of Gerfen ('85).
The immunoperoxidase method offers the advantage of yielding permanent sections in which large microscopic fields can be screened at low power.

However, since in every case the tracer was also incorporated by some non-NA cells in the vicinity of the LC (see below), labeling with PHA-L was not considered sufficient for identification of LC axons.
To overcome the problem, we analyzed a second set of sections stained wit,h the double-immunofluorescence method to recognize specifically LC axons from other PHA-L labeled fibers.
The combination of these two methods made it possible to establish an accurate picture of the distribution of LC axons in the brainstem.
For data presentation, the distribution of labeled LC axons was plotted with the aid of a cornputer-assisted mapping system.
Contours of sections were recorded by using a low magnification (4x) lens.
PHA-L labeled axons in these sections were subsequently mapped in darkfield at higher magnification (16 or 25x).
Double-immunofluorescence of PHA-I, and
DBH

Sections processed for double-immunofluorescence staining were incubated free-floating overnight with a mixture of anti-PHA-L antiserum (1:1,000) and anti-DBH antiserum (1:1,000) in PRS containing 1% normal goat serum and 0.2"s Triton X-100; sections were then rinsed in PRS and incubated for 1 hour with fluorescein isothiocyanate(FITC) -conjugated goat anti-rabbit immunoglobulins (IgG) (150, Zymed) and rhodamine-labeled goat anti-guinea pig 1gG (1:100, Kirkegaard and Perry).
Sections were rinsed, mounted onto gelatin-coated slides, air-dried, and coverslipped with buffered glycerol (pH 8.5).
Cross-reactivity between antibodies was abolished by affinity purification of the secondary antisera.
Antibody affinity columns were prepared according to the method of Cuatrecasas ('70).

Goat anti-guinea pig antibodies were passed over an affinity column containing rabbit IgG covalently linked to Sepharose 4R; goat anti-rabbit antibodies were passed over an affinity column containing guinea pig IgG covalently linked to Sepharose 4B.

To determine whether PHA-L labeled axons were LC axons, sections were examined in a Leitz fluorescence microscope with different filter combinations for FITC and rhodamine (Kosofsky and Molliver, '87; Fritschy et al., '87; Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
Double-labeled axons could be identiried reliably only at high magnification (1OOx Neofluoar lens) because of the high density of DBH immunoreactive fibers in some brainstem regions (see Fig. 1).

Individual PHA-L labeled fibers were first identified by using a filter combination for FITC; the filter setting was then switched to the rhodamine filter combination to determine whether that fiber was also DRH-immunoreactive.

This analysis was conducted systematically in a 1 in 6 series rif sections in all areas of the brainstem containing PHA-L labeled axons to evaluate the proportion of laheled axons that were noradrenergic.
DBH immunohistochemistry

To visualize the distribution of NA axons within the brainstem, a one in six series of sections through the midbrain arid hindbrain was stained with antibodies to rat DBH according to the immunoperoxidase method.
This protocol has been described in detail elsewhere (Fritschy and Grzanna, '89).

Results.S: Distribution of NA axons within the brainstem
NA axons visualized with anti - DBH were observed throughout the brainstem , with striking regional differences in density .

Raphe nuclei , the midbrain central gray , the nucleus of the solitary tract , and the principal nucleus of the inferior olivary complex are among the regions which receive the highest density of NA axons ( Fig .
Except for oculomotor nuclei , motor nuclei of the brainstem also receive a very dense NA input .
An extensive plexus of ' NA axons was observed throughout the brainstem reticular formation ( Fig . 1 ) .
By comparison , somatic afferent nuclei receive a lower density of NA axons , particularly the vestibular nuclei and dorsal column nuclei .
Many NA axons , mostly oriented within the plane of section , were observed in the inferior and superior colliculi .

TTE.S: The results of this study are based on the analysis of 18 cases.
The location of each injection was determined by staining sections for both PHA - L and DBH immunofluorescence .
Only those cases were analyzed in which iontophoresis of PHA - L resulted in a small deposit of lectin ( 50 - 200 pm in diameter ) within the confines of the LC .
In these cases , most labeled neurons were identified as DBH immunoreactive , i . e . as NA neurons of the LC ( Fig . 2 ) .
In addition , some PHA - L labeled non - NA cells were found up to several hundred microns away from the center of the injection .
The number of labeled LC neurons typically ranged from 20 to 100.
The use of ' pipets with large diameter tips ( 15 - 25 pm ) led to large deposits of lectin at the site of the injection but did not increase the number of labeled axons in the brainstem .
Distribution of pm - L labeled locus coedeus

To compare the density of PHA - I , labeled LC axons in the brainstem to that in brain regions which receive a prominent projection from the LC , a representative set of sections through the cerebral cortex and the cerebellum was analyzed .
All our injections labeled numerous LC axons in these regions , as illustrated in Figure 3, which depicts labeling typically seen in the cerebral cortex .
In comparison , labeling was much less extensive in the brainstern , where large territories appeared virtually devoid of labeled axons .
When injections of tracer were almost entirely confined to the LC ( Fig . 2 ) , PHA - L labeled axons were observed only in a few areas of the brainstem ( see below ) .
In contrast , injections of PHA - L extending laterally or ventrally beyond the limits of the LC resulted in widespread axonal labeling throughout the brainstem .
This difference in labeling was striking in the mesencephalic and medullary reticular formation , notably in the midbrain raphe nuclei and in the ventro - lateral medulla .
In all these regions injections confined to the LC produce very little axonal labeling .
Double - immunofluorescence staining revealed unequivocally that the extensive labeling observed in the core of the brainstem consisted almost , exclusively of non - NA axons .
As expected , in regions which receive a Drominent LC innut . such as the tectum or 1 , the cochlear nuclei , the vast majority of PHA - L labeled axons could be identified as LC axons ( Fig . 4 ) .
The interpeduncular nucleus , midbrain central uav . and facial nucleus I " typically contained a mixture of singleand double - labeled fibers .
The following description of YHA - L labeled LC axons in the brainstem ( Fig . 5 ) is based upon their definitive identification by double - immunofluorescence .
At the level of the injection sites ( Fig . 5C ) , PHA - L labeled LC axons were present bilaterally .

On the side of the injection axons could be followed in several directions : laterally towards the cochlear nucleus and the principal trigeminal nucleus , rostrally into the ascending dorsal bundle , ventrally into a region just medial to the motor trigeminal nucleus , and caudally into the vestibular nuclear complex .
Labeled LC axons were also observed crossing the midline .
At this level , the principal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve and the dorsal corhlear nucleus contained the highest numbers of labeled fibers .
The contralateral LC contained a moderate number of labeled axons .
In the midbrain ( Figs . 5A , B ) , LC axons were distributed bilaterally to the superior and inferior colliculi ( Figs . 6, 7 ) , central gray and interpeduncular nucleus ( Fig . 8 ) .
Most labeled LC axons in the central gray were seen lateral and dorsal to the aqueduct ; only occasionally did we observe LC axons in the dorsal raphe nucleus or in its vicinity .
In the interpeduncular nucleus , labeled axons were observed only following injections of PHA - 1, involving the rostral part of the LC .
Labeled LC axons were consistently found in the ascending dorsal bundle . ventrolateral to the central gray ( Fig . 5B ) .
In contrast to extensive labeling in tectum and central gray , few T , C axons were observed in the midbrain tegmentum .
Of notice , no LC axons were present in the median raphe , nor in the dopaminergic cell groups of the substantia nigra and ventral tegmental area .
In the pons and medulla ( Figs . 5D - F ) , labeled LC axons were primarily distributed bilaterally to sensory nuclei .
For example , labeled LC axons were found in all subdivisions of the cochlear nucleus ( Fig . 9 ) and in the entire trigeminal sensory complex ( Fig .
LO).
Occasionally , LC axons were observed in the dorsal column nuclei .
In contrast to somatic afferent nuclei , very few LC axons were observed in the nucleus of the solitary tract and commissural nucleus .
Labeled LC axons were also observed in the pontine nuclei , in the nucleus praepositus hypoglossi and in the inferior olivary complex .
The principal nucleus of the inferior olive contained a high density of labeled fibers bilaterally ( Fig . 11 ) .
Motor nuclei of the brainstem were almost devoid of LC axons .
The only exception is the facial nucleus , in which all our injections labeled a few LC axons .
In the rostral medulla , descending LC axons could be seen travelling mainly ipsilaterally through the vestibular nuclear complex ( Fig . 5D ) .
In the caudal medulla , only few descending axons were observed in the position of the descending catecholamine bundle ( Jones and Friedman , ' 83 ) .
Except around the inject , ion site , the pontine and medullary reticular formation contained few labeled LC axons ( Fig . 10 ) .
Most notably , pontine and medullary raphe nuclei were virtually devoid of LC axons ( Fig . 5D - F ) .

The overall density of labeling in the brainstem appeared to depend on the location of the injections of PHA - L within the LC : injections into the dorsal LC labeled , more fibers in the mesencephalon than did injections into the ventral LC .
The reverse was observed for LC axons distribution in the medulla .
In addition , PHA - L labeled LC axons were not uniformly distributed in sensory nuclei and tectum , but appeared in patches .
In the spinal trigeminal nucleus . for example , patches of dense labeling alternated irregularly with regions almost devoid of labeling .

Results.S: The location of the patches varied from case to case, although no consistent pattern could be identified.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
In the present study we have analyzed the distribution of T,C axons within the brainstem by using PHA-L as an anterograde tracer.
The principal new finding is that LC efferents in the brainstem are largely restricted to somatic afferent nuclei and the tectum.
In contrast, the core of the brainstem receives little input from the LC.
These findings suggest that the influence of'the LC on brainstem functions is more specific than was previously suspected.
The use of PHA-L as tracer permits visualization of the axonal tree of labeled neurons with extraordinary sensitivity and resolution.
The advantages of the PHA-T, method to trace LC projections over conventional tracing methods have been discussed in a previous report (Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
The present results show that identification of the NA nature of PHA-I, laheled axons is critical to determine unambiguously the distribution of LC efferents to the brainstem.
Most injections labeled non-NA neurons in the vicinity of the LC and hence resulted in labeling of non-NA axons.

The distribution of these fibers within the brainstem was quite different from that of LC axons, in that they were most, numerous in regions almost devoid of LC axons, notahly in raphe nuclei, the reticular formation and the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus nerve.

Our observations that many non-NA axons were labeled following tracer injections into the LC may account for the major discrepancies between the results of this and previous anterograde tracing studies which reported LC projections to raphe nuclei, medullary reticular formation and the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve (Pickel et al., '74; McRride and Sulin, '76; Westlund and Coult,er, '80; Jones and Yang, '85; Cowan and Park, Due to the small size of iontophoretic injections of PHAL, only a fraction of all LC neurons was labeled in each case.

To verify that the sparse labeling of axons in the core of the brainstem did not result from a failure of LC neurons to incorporate or transport the tracer, we also examined sections through the cerebral cortex (Fig. 3), cerebellum. and spinal cord (Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).

In these sections, our injections typically labeled numerous axons, indicating that the comparatively sparse labeling in the brainstem reflects a paucity of LC axons terminals rather than a lack of labeling.
There is evidence ftm a topographical organization within the LC with respect to its forebrain and spinal cord projections (Mason and Fibiger, '79; Loughlin et al., '86).
To avoid a sampling bias in our analysis of the LC projections to the brainstem, we studied a large number of cases in which the injections of PHA-L were placed in different parts of the LC.
Our cases include all parts of the LC proper, except the rostra1 tip of the nucleus, which is composed of neurons scattered through the ventrolateral central gray (Grzanna and Molliver, '80).
We are therefore confident that the results reported here provide a representative summary of the distribution of LC axons within the brainstem.

The LC is a major contributor to the NA innervation of the spinal cord and most of the forebrain (Ungerstedt, '71; Lindvall and Bjorklund, '74; Ross and Reis, '74; Swanson and Hartman, '74; Levitt and Moore, '78; Morrison et al., '79, '81; Bjiirklund and Skagerberg, '82; Lyons et al., '89; Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).
The most unexpected result of this study is the modest contribution of the LC to the dense NA innervation of the brainstem.
The paucity of LC input to the core of the brainstem is particularly striking.

This finding is at variance with the results of previous studies which used anterograde transport of tritiated amino acids to characterize brainstem projections of the LC (Westlund and Coulter, '80; ?
Jones and Yang, '85).
These studies concluded that the LC has widespread projections to numerous brainstem areas, including the reticular formation, cranial nerve nuclei, and several monoaminergic cell groups.

We have not been able to trace LC axons into the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra pars compacta, regions which have been reported to receive an input from the LC (Pasquier et al., '77; Phillipson, '79; Simon et al., '79; Geyer and Lee, '84).
Previous studies also suspected the LC to provide a prominent input to the dorsal raphe nucleus (Chu and Bloom, '74; Sakai et al.. '77; Geyer and Lee, '84; Cowan and Park, '86).
Our data indicate that the LC does not project to raphe nuclei. except for a small input to the dorsal raphe nucleus.
Thus, the extensive NA input to raphe nuclei and brainstem reticular formation (Fig. 1) appears to originate from nonLC NA neurons.

Our findings support the results of several retrograde transport studies which concluded that the dense NA innervation of brainstem motor nuclei does not originate in the LC (Traverc, and Norgren, '83; Vornov and Sutin, '83; Grzanna et al., '87; Lyons and Grzanna, '88).

Our results also agree with previous findings ihat oisceral afferent nuclei are not innervated by the LC (Takahashi et al., '79; Thor and Helke. '88), although these autonomic centers are characterized by a very dense NA input (Kalia et al., '85).
Most notably, no LC axons could be traced to brainstem areas involved in cardiovascular functions.

Our observations do not support the hypothesis that the LC controls directly cardiovascular functions such as arterial pressure or heart rate by means of projections to brainstem visceromotor nuclei (set.
Olpe et al., '85 for review).

Our results confirm the projections of the LC to afferent nuclei in the brainstem reported in previous studies (Levitt and Moore, '79; Kromer and Moore, '130; Senba et al., '81; Crr~anna et al., '87).
We observed numerous labeled axons in the cochlear nucleus, trigeminal complex, and throughout the tectum.
A few labeled axons were found in the vestibular complex and in the dorsal column nuclei.
This is consistent with the fact that these regions receive a sparse NA input.
Thus, our data indicate that the LC innervates all brainstem somatic afferent nuclei.
Whether other NA subgroups also project to these regions remains to be determined.

We observed that in the mesencephalon, ascending LC axons are localized ventrolateral to the central gray, in the position of the dorsal bundle (Lindvall and Rjorklund, '74; Swanson and Hartman, '74; ,Jones and Friedman, '83).
In the pons, descending LC axons were observed traveling through the vestibular nuclear complex, as described by Jones and Friedman ('83) for the cat.

These authors suggested that descending LC axons travel the length of the medulla within the longitudinal catecholamine bundle, and enter the lateral funiculus of the spinal cord (Jones and Friedman, '83) In the present study, we were unable to follow labeled LC axons through the medulla up to their entry into the spinal cord.
The number of labeled axons in the catecholamine bundle decreased markedly from rostral to caudal medullary levels.
We have recently shown that descend ing LC axons travel the length of the spinal cord within the superficial layers of the dorsal horn (Fritschy and Grzanna, '90).

We suspect that LC axons en route to the spinal cord leave the catecholamine bundle rostral to the bulbo-spinal junction and reach the superficial layers of the dorsal horn by passing through the spinal trigeminal nucleus pars caudalis.

Although the PHA-T, anterograde transport method is not ideally suited to uncover topographic projections of the IAC, our data suggest the existence of a crude topographic order in brainstem projections of IL!
neurons.
We observed consistent variations in labeling density in the midbrain and medulla depending upon the location of the injection sites within the 1,C.
Descending projections to the medulla appear to originate in more ventrally located cells of the LC, while projections to the midbrain arise from more dorsally placed neurons (Fig. 5).

A similar differential origin along the dorso-ventral axis holds for the coeruleo-spinal and coeruleo-cortical projections (Satoh et al., '77; Mason and Fibiger, '79; Guyenet, '80; Westlund et al., '83; Loughlin et al., '86; Lyons and Grzanna, '88).
Further studies using retrograde transport methods will be needed for a more detailed characterization of the topographic organization of LC efferents to brainstem nuclei.

The paucity of LC projections to large portions of the brainstem. most notably the reticular core. described in this report suggests that LC efferents are not as ubiquitous as previously suspected (Moore and Bloom, '79; Moore, '82).
In contrast to the widespread distribution of LC axons in the forebrain and spinal cord, the majority of NA axons in the brainstem are of non-LC origin.

This sets the LC apart from neurons in the immediately adjacent reticular formation which are characterized by prominent interconnections with different levels of the brainstem and by projcctions to motor nuclei (Jones and Yang, '85).
Our data support the conclusion that LC axons, while following similar paths to those of reticular neurons, appear to project most extensively to distant targets beyond the brainstem.
By virtue of its widespread projections, the LC has often been portrayed as a nucleus subserving very global functions.

This view is based heavily on neuroanatomical data and has only recently been challenged by the results of more refined tracing studies (Sawchenko and Swanson, '82; Grzanna et al.. '87; Lyons and Grzanna, '88; Fritschy and Grzanna, '90), and by the results of several electrophysiological studies (Aston-Jones and Bloom, '81; Aston-Jones et al., '84; Foote and Morrison, '87).
The data presented here show that the brainstem contains large territories only sparsely supplied by LC axons.
These anatomical findings call into doubt the notion that the LC exerts a global influence over brainstem functions.
In particular, a direct role of the LC in motor functions of the brainstem and the integrative [unctions of the reticular core appears unlikely.
The anatomical maps of the brainstem projections of the LC provided here should facilitate future studies into the role of the LC in brainstem functions.

Acknowledgements.S: Molliver for generously providing the computer-mapping system used for data collection in this study (USPHS grant NS-16654).
This work was supported by USPHS grant NIMH MH-41977.
